trial_identification.studytitle: A Pilot Study to Investigate Whether Visual Cues Assist the Elderly to Understand Imaginary Falls Scenarios.
trial_identification.scientifictitle: A Pilot Study to Investigate Whether Visual Cues Assist the Elderly to Understand Imaginary Falls Scenarios.

conditions.healthcondition: Elderly Rehabilitation Inpatients admitted due to any medical condition

interventions.interventions: The intervention is Visual cues to accompany survey questions. The intervention group will receive visual cues to accompany a survey involving questions about falls rates, imaginary falls scenarios of varying severities and willingness to pay for falls prevention questions. The duration of the intervention is the time taken to complete the survey. Each participant will complete the survey once only. We currently estimate that time taken to complete the survey will take approximately 90 minutes with no visual cues and perhaps 10 minutes less with visual cues.
interventions.comparator: The control group will complete the same survey but will not have visual cues to assist.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Patient recall and understanding of questions.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Measured after each scenario/question. Once the patient has answered each question they will be asked to recall key points about the scenario/question to demonstrate understanding.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Time taken to complete survey. The time taken to complete each section of the survey interview will be recorded during the interview and later analysed. If the intervention is effective it is likely to reduce the time taken to complete each section of the survey.

eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Cognitive Deficit, inability to verbally communicate effectively in English (eg. aphasic stroke patient).

ethicsAndSummary.summary: This study aims to identify whether visual cues assist elderly hospital inpatients to understand imaginary falls scenarios and other questions about falls and falls prevention strategies.
